description: The Golden Bridge (Cau Vang) is a breathtaking 150-meter-long pedestrian bridge suspended 1,414 meters above sea level in the Ba Na Hills resort near Da Nang, Vietnam. Opened in June 2018, this architectural marvel features two massive weathered stone hands appearing to lift a golden silk ribbon through the clouds, though the hands are actually constructed from fiberglass and wire mesh designed to look centuries old. Designed by TA Landscape Architecture under the direction of architect Vu Viet Anh, the bridge was conceived to invoke the sensation of walking along a thread stretching through the hands of God, representing the Mountain Genie drawing a strip of golden silk from the rocky hillside to help travelers reach paradise. The bridge's 5-meter-wide deck features wooden panels and gold-plated railings adorned with purple chrysanthemums, Vietnam's flowers of love and happiness. Accessible only via the world's longest cable car system (a 20-minute ride covering 5,771 meters), the bridge has earned international acclaim from CNN, BBC, The Guardian, and TIME Magazine, which named it among the World's 100 Greatest Places of 2018. The World Travel Awards recognized it as The World's Leading Iconic Tourist Bridge for four consecutive years from 2020 to 2023. Built between October 2017 and April 2018 by over 100 workers and artists at a cost of nearly 2 billion USD including surrounding landscapes, the bridge loops nearly back around to itself, creating a unique curved pathway that offers uninterrupted views of the rolling Truong Son Mountains and, on clear days, the sight of clouds floating below.
highlights: Two giant hands constructed from fiberglass and wire mesh, each supported by anatomical skeletal frames and covered with moss and cracks to appear as weathered stone hundreds of years old, cradle the bridge 1,414 meters (4,600 feet) above sea level.
The 150-meter-long bridge features gold-plated railings that shimmer in the sunlight, creating a stunning contrast against the lush green mountains and earning its name as the Golden Bridge.

Access requires riding the Guinness World Record-holding cable car system, the world's longest at 5,771 meters, offering a spectacular 20-minute journey sweeping over rugged peaks, waterfalls, and clouds.
Purple chrysanthemums line both sides of the 3-meter-wide pedestrian walkway, representing love and happiness in Vietnamese culture and adding vibrant color to the golden structure.
The bridge's unique looping design curves nearly back around to itself across eight connected sections, creating dramatic photo opportunities from multiple angles.
At sunset between 5-6pm, the golden railings intensify in color as the setting sun illuminates the structure, while the giant hands appear sacred and awe-inspiring against the evening sky.
The hands are positioned with each finger carefully chosen to invoke the designer's vision of divine protection, with the skeletal frames following precise anatomical structures for authenticity.
On early mornings between 7:30-9:30am, visitors can experience the bridge above a sea of clouds, with fresh mountain air and soft light perfect for photography before crowds arrive.
The bridge connects to Le Jardin D'Amour flower garden, creating a pathway through paradise with panoramic views of the Truong Son Mountains stretching into the distance.
Despite appearing ancient, the entire structure was completed in just six months between October 2017 and April 2018, showcasing modern engineering disguised as timeless architecture.
tips: Arrive at the cable car base station by 7:00-7:30am to catch the first cars up and experience the bridge before massive crowds arrive around 9:00am, or visit between 5-6pm when most tourists have left.
Consider staying overnight at a Ba Na Hills hotel to access the bridge during the magical 7:00-9:00am window when it's least crowded and often above the clouds.
Visit between February and August for sunny, dry weather with the best views, but avoid mid-May to mid-July when Vietnamese students are on summer vacation and crowds peak.
Skip weekends and Vietnamese holidays entirely if you want to avoid competing with dozens of professional wedding photographers and brides doing photo shoots on the bridge.
Purchase the 950,000 VND (39 USD) entrance ticket that includes round-trip cable car, Golden Bridge access, Fantasy Park, Linh Ung Pagoda, and Le Jardin D'Amour flower garden.
Wear comfortable walking shoes as you'll cover significant distance across Ba Na Hills, and bring layers since temperatures at 1,414 meters can be 10 degrees cooler than Da Nang below.
Take the cable car from Bordeaux Station (near Golden Bridge) to Louvre Station in French Village for lunch at Four Seasons Restaurant's 90-dish international buffet (10:30am-3pm).
Stop at Debay Ancient Wine Cellar, located just 500 meters from Golden Bridge, for premium wine and grilled meat skewers with mountain views.
Be prepared for unpredictable weather changes at high altitude, fog can roll in quickly and completely obscure views, though some visitors find the mysterious foggy atmosphere even more dramatic.
Allocate at least 4-5 hours for your Ba Na Hills visit to fully experience the Golden Bridge, cable car rides, French Village, and other attractions without feeling rushed.
Download the Ba Na Hills map or take photos of signage as the complex is massive and it's easy to get disoriented between different cable car stations.
Book tickets online in advance during peak season to avoid long queues at the base station, and remember that Da Nang residents get discounted tickets at 600,000 VND.
vibe: Standing on the Golden Bridge feels like stepping into a fantastical realm where ancient mythology meets modern Instagram culture. The surreal experience of walking along a golden pathway held aloft by colossal weathered hands, suspended in the clouds at nearly 1,500 meters, creates an almost dreamlike atmosphere that's unlike any other bridge in the world. In the early morning hours, when mist swirls around the structure and you're among just a handful of visitors, there's a genuine sense of walking through the hands of God, with the purple chrysanthemums adding an ethereal beauty and the distant mountains creating a majestic backdrop. However, by mid-morning, the vibe shifts dramatically as tour groups flood in, wedding parties commandeer sections for elaborate photo shoots, and the peaceful sanctuary transforms into a bustling outdoor photography studio where everyone jostles for the perfect Instagram shot. The juxtaposition is striking: the bridge's design evokes ancient spirituality and timeless grandeur, yet it sits within a Disneyland-style theme park complex complete with French village replicas and fantasy attractions. The temperature is refreshingly cool compared to Da Nang's tropical heat below, and the fresh mountain air adds to the sense of escape. When fog rolls in, the bridge becomes even more mysterious, with the hands emerging from clouds like a scene from a fantasy film. It's simultaneously awe-inspiring and artificial, spiritual and commercial, serene and chaotic, depending entirely on when you visit and how you frame your experience.
expectations: The Golden Bridge is an ancient structure with centuries-old stone hands that have supported travelers for generations.
You'll have the iconic bridge mostly to yourself for peaceful walks and unobstructed photo opportunities, just like the stunning images on Instagram.
The bridge is a standalone natural attraction in the mountains, easily accessible without navigating a large commercial theme park complex.
The hands are made of carved stone or concrete and the golden color is natural metal or paint that's part of the original mountain landscape.
Weather will be consistently clear with guaranteed panoramic mountain views since you're traveling specifically to see this famous landmark.
reality: The bridge was only completed in April 2018, making it barely six years old, and the weathered hands are fiberglass and wire mesh deliberately aged with moss and cracks to appear ancient.

Unless you arrive on the first cable car at 7am or visit during the late afternoon after 5pm, you'll be competing with hundreds of tourists and professional wedding photographers who literally tell visitors to move out of their shots.

The Golden Bridge sits within Sun World Ba Na Hills, a massive Disney-style amusement park complex requiring a 950,000 VND ticket, cable car rides between stations, and navigation through French Village replicas, wax museums, and fantasy attractions.

The hands are modern fiberglass construction designed by TA Landscape Architecture, the railings are gold-plated steel, and the entire structure cost nearly 2 billion USD as part of a commercial resort development.

At 1,414 meters elevation, weather changes rapidly and unpredictably, fog can completely obscure views within minutes, and rain is common, meaning many visitors never see the clear mountain vistas from promotional photos.
unique_facts: The bridge's principal architect, Vu Viet Anh, conceived the giant hands design while observing Ba Na mountain and imagining standing on the hands of a deity, wanting to create a pathway between heaven and earth.

Each hand is supported by internal skeletal frames modeled precisely after human anatomical structures, with every finger position carefully calculated to invoke the feeling of divine protection and guidance.

The bridge went viral on social media so quickly after its June 2018 opening that more than 3.5 million people visited Da Nang in just the first half of 2023, many coming specifically to see this one attraction.

The cable car system required to access the bridge holds the Guinness World Record as the world's longest non-stop single-track cable car at 5,771 meters, operating 86 cabins that each carry 10 passengers.
Purple chrysanthemums were specifically chosen to line the bridge because they symbolize love and happiness in Vietnamese culture, adding cultural meaning beyond the structure's visual impact.
The bridge's design intentionally loops nearly back around to itself, creating an impossible-looking curved pathway that enhances the sensation of floating through space in the hands of God.
Despite the hands appearing centuries old with moss and weathered cracks, the entire construction took just six months from October 2017 to April 2018 with over 100 specialized workers and artists.
The golden railings are made from titanium-plated stainless steel plates, not painted gold, ensuring the shimmering color remains brilliant even in the harsh mountain weather conditions.

TIME Magazine named it among the World's 100 Greatest Places of 2018 within months of opening, while the World Travel Awards crowned it The World's Leading Iconic Tourist Bridge for four consecutive years (2020-2023).
The bridge sits at exactly 1,414 meters above sea level, putting it above the cloud layer on many mornings, creating the illusion of walking through heaven with clouds flowing beneath your feet.
According to Vietnamese legend, the hands represent the Mountain Genie drawing a golden silk ribbon from the mountainside to guide villagers to the Thien Thai paradise garden hidden in the peaks.

The bridge's design was inspired by ancient Vietnamese mythology, but its execution uses cutting-edge fiberglass molding and wire mesh techniques typically reserved for theme park attractions and movie sets.
surprises: The bridge is accessed through a full-scale French Village replica complete with cobblestone streets, European architecture, and a mini Notre Dame cathedral, creating a jarring cultural mashup before reaching the iconic hands.

Professional wedding photographers essentially control the bridge during peak hours, with dozens of brides in full wedding gowns and elaborate entourages who will ask (or demand) tourists to move out of their carefully staged shots.

The entire Ba Na Hills complex feels more like Disneyland than a natural mountain attraction, with Fantasy Park gaming arcades, wax museums, and Alpine Coasters competing with the bridge for attention.

On foggy days when visibility drops to near zero, the bridge actually becomes more atmospheric and mysterious, with many visitors preferring the ethereal experience over clear weather's tourist crowds.

The wooden deck planks are perfectly maintained modern materials, not ancient wood, and the 5-meter width includes 1-meter flowerbeds on each side, leaving only 3 meters for actual pedestrian traffic.

Debay Ancient Wine Cellar sits just 500 meters from this supposedly ancient bridge, offering German-style beer and grilled sausages in a themed European restaurant that completely breaks any cultural immersion.

The cable car journey itself is arguably as spectacular as the bridge, offering 20 minutes of aerial views over untouched jungle, waterfalls, and clouds that create a sense of adventure before the crowds hit.
Despite the hands appearing to support the bridge, the actual structural load is carried by concealed modern steel supports, with the hands serving purely decorative and thematic purposes.
Local Vietnamese people rarely visit for the bridge itself, instead coming to practice religion at the nearby Linh Ung Pagoda or escape Da Nang's heat in Ba Na's naturally cool mountain climate.
The bridge's golden color intensifies dramatically at sunset between 5-6pm, becoming far more spectacular than midday visits, yet most tour groups depart by 3pm and miss this optimal lighting.

You can see the cable car gondolas passing directly beneath the bridge every few minutes, creating unexpected modern intrusions into what's meant to feel like a timeless, floating pathway through divine hands.

The entire experience costs roughly the same as a full day at Disney World when factoring in entrance fees, cable cars, and meals, making it Vietnam's most expensive single-attraction ticket at 950,000 VND per person.
